item.item: Instances of this type are used to assess the red list assessment category.

A taxon is Critically Endangered when the best available evidence indicates that it meets any of the criteria A to E for Critically Endangered (see Section V), and it is therefore considered to be facing an extremely high risk of extinction in the wild.

A taxon is Data Deficient when there is inadequate information to make a direct, or indirect, assessment of its risk of extinction based on its distribution and/or population status. A taxon in this category may be well studied, and its biology well known, but appropriate data on abundance and/or distribution are lacking. Data Deficient is therefore not a category of threat. Listing of taxa in this category indicates that more information is required and acknowledges the possibility that future research will show that threatened classification is appropriate. It is important to make positive use of whatever data are available. In many cases great care should be exercised in choosing between DD and a threatened status. If the range of a taxon is suspected to be relatively circumscribed, and a considerable period of time has elapsed since the last record of the taxon, threatened status may well be justified.

A taxon is Endangered when the best available evidence indicates that it meets any of the criteria A to E for Endangered (see Section V), and it is therefore considered to be facing a very high risk of extinction in the wild.

A taxon is Extinct in the Wild when it is known only to survive in cultivation, in captivity or as a naturalized population (or populations) well outside the past range. A taxon is presumed Extinct in the Wild when exhaustive surveys in known and/or expected habitat, at appropriate times (diurnal, seasonal, annual), throughout its historic range have failed to record an individual. Surveys should be over a time frame appropriate to the taxon?s life cycle and life form.

A taxon is Extinct when there is no reasonable doubt that the last individual has died. A taxon is presumed Extinct when exhaustive surveys in known and/or expected habitat, at appropriate times (diurnal, seasonal, annual), throughout its historic range have failed to record an individual. Surveys should be over a time frame appropriate to the taxon?s life cycle and life form.

A taxon is Least Concern when it has been evaluated against the criteria and does not qualify for Critically Endangered, Endangered, Vulnerable or Near Threatened. Widespread and abundant taxa are included in this category.
A taxon is Not Evaluated when it is has not yet been evaluated against the criteria.

A taxon is Near Threatened when it has been evaluated against the criteria but does not qualify for Critically Endangered, Endangered or Vulnerable now, but is close to qualifying for or is likely to qualify for a threatened category in the near future.

A taxon is Vulnerable when the best available evidence indicates that it meets any of the criteria A to E for Vulnerable (see Section V), and it is therefore considered to be facing a high risk of extinction in the wild.
Instances of this type are used to assess the red list assessment criteria.
Geographic range size, and fragmentation, decline or fluctuations.
Small population size and fragmentation, decline, or fluctuations.
Very small population or very restricted distribution.
Quantitative analysis of extinction risk (e.g., population viability analysis).
Instances of this type are used to assess the red list assessment category.
Intentional use (species being assessed is the target)
Unintentional effects (species being assessed is not the target)
Intentional use (species being assessed is the target)
Unintentional effects (species being assessed is not the target)
Intentional use: subsistence/small scale (species being assessed is the target) [harvest]
Intentional use: large scale (species being assessed is the target) [harvest]
Unintentional effects: subsistence/small scale (species being assessed is not the target) [harvest]
Unintentional effects: large scale (species being assessed is not the target) [harvest]
Intentional use: subsistence/small scale (species being assessed is the target) [harvest]
Intentional use: large scale (species being assessed is the target) [harvest]
Unintentional effects: subsistence/small scale (species being assessed is not the target) [harvest]
Unintentional effects: large scale (species being assessed is not the target) [harvest]
Invasive & other problematic species, genes & diseases
This type qualifies the conservation actions.

Forest consists of a continuous stand of trees and includes both forested areas (generally with a closed canopy) and wooded areas (canopy more open but see also savanna). Primary and secondary forest habitats and forest edge are all included.

Distributed across the high latitudes of the northern hemisphere (occurring from c.35 N at high elevations). Trees are predominantly coniferous, though a few deciduous genera are nearly ubiquitous in their distribution and are locally common. Includes forest types described as taiga, steppe, tundra, coniferous, coniferous deciduous, and broadleaved deciduous.
Included for completeness sake – probably little forest at these high latitudes.
Stunted forest on subantarctic islands (e.g. Auckland/Snares Islands NZ).

Distributed in the temperate regions of North and South America (primarily Chile), Europe, Asia (China/Korea/Japan) and Australia/New Zealand. Includes forest types described as coniferous, broadleaved evergreen, broadleaved deciduous, and mixed; also riverine and alluvial.

Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia. Typically forests that experience a dry season of several months. Includes forest types described as deciduous, makatea, atoll/beach, palm, thorn and spiny.

Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia, generally below c.1,200 m (varying with geography and topography). Includes (lowland/hill rain/wet/humid/moist) forest types described as evergreen or semi-evergreen or broadleaved evergreen, deciduous, dipterocarp and mixed; also riparian/riverine and gallery.
Distributed in the subtropics and tropics, growing in sheltered estuaries and along coastlines in brackish or salt water.

Distributed in the subtropics and tropics. Typically flooded for at least part of the year and dependent on this flooding for its existence. Includes forest types described as peat swamp, bog, and varzea/igapo.

Distributed in the subtropical/tropical regions of the Neotropics, Africa and Indo-Malesia, generally above c.1,200 m (varying with geography and topography). Includes (lower and upper montane/mountain rain/wet/moist) forest types described as cloud, mossy, elfin, dwarf, Polylepis, coniferous, pine, pine-oak and evergreen.

Savannas are ecosystems dominated by a grass ground cover with an overstorey of widely spaced trees. May be referred to as savanna woodlands, savanna parklands, savanna grasslands, low tree/shrub savannas, thicket/scrub savannas. Distributed largely in Africa, Australia (mostly northern), Asia (India, SE Asia) and South America.
Includes savanna types described as Eucalyptus and Acacia woodland, mopane/miombo/Brachystegia woodlands (Africa), cerrado/campos/caatinga (Brazil) and mulga (Australia).
Includes savanna types described as pantanal (Brazil/Bolivia/Paraguay), chaco (Paraguay/Bolivia/Argentina), and llanos (Venezuela/Colombia).
Also referred to as scrub, bushland and thicket.
Includes (arid/semi-desert/dry) shrubland types described as succulent, thorn, karoo (South Africa), restingas (coastal scrub in Brazil). Found mainly on the lowlands.
Includes (humid/semi-humid) shrubland types described as evergreen; also river island and riparian. Found mainly on the lowlands.
Includes (alpine/subalpine) shrubland types around and above the tree-line in mountainous regions, e.g. dominated by rhododendron, juniper or birch.

Distributed in Mediterranean ecosystems of Australia, Chile, Europe/North Africa, North America (primarily California) and South Africa. Evergreen shrubs and sclerophyllous trees (low in stature with a relatively open canopy) are the dominant plant forms, and frequent fires have historically played and important role in regulating community composition and structure. Includes shrubland types described as garrigue, chaparral, maquis (New Caledonia), mallee (Australia), matorral (Chile) and fynbos (South Africa).
Grassland consists of land covered with grasses and other herbs, either without woody plants, or the latter very sparsely distributed (see also savanna).
Grasslands which have developed over permafrost.
Includes grassland types described as prairies, steppe, calcareous, siliceous, edaphic and pampas.
Includes (arid/dry) grassland types described as hummock/tussock (Australia).
Includes (alpine/subalpine/highveld) grassland types described as paramos, altiplanos and puna.

Wetlands correspond to the wetland types recognised by Ramsar. NB. Includes only inland waters – other types are covered by “Coastline”. Note also that forested wetlands are dealt with under the forest types above.
Shrub swamps, shrub-dominated freshwater marshes, shrub carr, alder thicket on inorganic soils.
Over 8 ha. Includes large oxbow lakes.
Ponds (below 8 ha), marshes and swamps on inorganic soils; with emergent vegetation water-logged for at least most of the growing season.
Below 8 ha. On inorganic soils; includes sloughs, potholes, seasonally flooded meadows, sedge marshes.
Includes tundra pools and temporary waters from snowmelt.
Includes alpine meadows, temporary waters from snowmelt.
Permanent Saline, Brackish or Alkaline Lakes
Seasonal/Intermittent Saline, Brackish or Alkaline Lakes and Flats
Permanent Saline, Brackish or Alkaline Marshes/Pools
Seasonal/Intermittent Saline, Brackish or Alkaline Marshes/Pools
Karst and Other Subterranean Hydrological Systems
Includes inland cliffs, mountain peaks, talus, feldmark.

Desert consists of arid landscapes with a sparse plant cover, except in depressions where water accumulates. The sandy, stony or rocky substrate contributes more to the appearance of the landscape than does the vegetation.
It is recognized that this marine habitat classification (which largely follows that used by Ramsar) is inadequate and that this will be improved in due course
Usually <6m deep at low tide. Includes sea bays and straits.
Includes kelp beds, sea-grass beds and tropical marine meadows.
The coastal habitats are those used by Ramsar.
Includes rocky offshore islands and sea cliffs.
Includes sand bars, spits, sandy islets and dune systems (including humid dune slacks).
Includes river channels below the tidal limit and coastal deltas.
Intertidal Mud, Sand or Salt Flats
Unvegetated sands and muds, submerged for part of every tide.

Includes salt marshes, which are submerged by high tides at some stage of the annual tidal cycle. Also includes salt meadows, saltings, raised salt marshes; including tidal brackish and freshwater marshes.
Brackish to saline lagoons with at least one relatively narrow connection to the sea. Often formed from sea inlets by silting and cut off from the sea by sand or mud banks.
Karst and Other Subterranean Hydrological Systems
Includes fertilised or re-seeded permanent grasslands, sometimes treated with selective herbicides, with very impoverished flora and fauna.
Occurs throughout the world. Usually metropolitan and commercial areas dominated by asphalt, concrete and roof. Includes buildings, lawns and parks.
A type specifically introduced for the Global Amphibian Assessment.
These human-made wetland habitats are those used by Ramsar.
Generally over 8 ha. Includes reservoirs, barrages, dams and impoundments.
Generally below 8 ha. Includes farm ponds, stock ponds, small tanks.
For example, fish or shrimp ponds.
Gravel, brick, clay pits, borrow pits and mining pools.
Sewage farms, settling ponds, oxidation basins, etc.
Includes irrigation channels and paddy (rice) fields.
Including intensively managed or grazed wet meadow or pasture.
Karst and Other Subterrranean Hydrological Systems
Includes only non-cultivated species or those that have escaped from cultivation.
Main or preferred habitat/s, habitat/s containing major subpopulations, habitat/s with high population densities.
Secondary habitat/s, habitat/s containing minor subpopulations, habitat/s with low population densities.
Unsuitability expressly known or easily inferred from the ecology of the taxon.
Data deficient, possibly suitable or moderately suitable as inferred from ecology of the taxon.
